body:
Comment 13: 
Personally, I do not believe that the considerable effort will pay off here.
The code will be quite complex, and it will have to be some kind of
sub-dialect of Go to avoid using the things that it is implementing.
Using C is much simpler.
Very little of the runtime is that performance critical. The small parts
that are, like the hash function, can be written in assembly.
Put another way, there is a finite and non-growing amount of C code in the
runtime. There's no asymptotic benefit to switching it over to Go.
